observations: The input is a 3x3 grid containing a color and zeros.
The output is a 9x9 grid, which can be seen as a 3x3 tiling of 3x3 blocks.
Each 3x3 block in the output corresponds to a cell in the input grid.
If an input cell (i, j) has a non-zero value, the corresponding 3x3 block in the output (from row 3i to 3i+2 and column 3j to 3j+2) is an exact copy of the entire 3x3 input grid.
If an input cell (i, j) is zero, the corresponding 3x3 block in the output is filled entirely with zeros.
hypotheses: The output is generated by replacing every non-zero pixel in the 3x3 input with the 3x3 input grid itself, and replacing every zero pixel with a 3x3 block of zeros.
This is a specific form of a block-wise substitution or fractal-like expansion (Kronecker product-like) where the template is the input itself.

rejected_hypotheses.hypothesis: The output is a simple 3x3 scaling (magnification) of the input.
rejected_hypotheses.reason: Magnification would result in each pixel becoming a 3x3 block of its own color. In these examples, a single pixel is replaced by the pattern of the whole input grid.

selected_rule: For each cell A[i][j] in the 3x3 input grid, the output block B[i][j] (at row 3i, col 3j) is: if A[i][j] != 0, B[i][j] = A; if A[i][j] == 0, B[i][j] = 0 (3x3).
step_plan: Initialize a 9x9 output grid with zeros.
Iterate through each cell (i, j) of the input grid A.
Copy the 3x3 input grid A into the output grid starting at position (3i, 3j).
If A[i][j] is zero, leave the 3x3 block at (3i, 3j) as zeros (which it already is by initialization).
